title: High school football: Close win makes it two in a row for Morton
text:
High school football: Morton shows potential, hangs tough with Lyons Township 
So Darin Gipson rewrote the ending. 
Gipson scored on a two-point conversion with 1:20 remaining in the fourth quarter and the host Mustangs held on for a thrilling 15-14 West Suburban Gold victory against Leyden on Oct. 16. 
The win was the second straight for Morton (3-5, 3-2), which stunned Addison Trail 13-7 in double overtime the week before. 
It appeared the Mustangs were headed for overtime again after Greg Hoard scored on a 9-yard touchdown run to pull his team within 14-13. 
Morton lined up to kick the extra point, but when the Eagles (3-5, 2-3) jumped offsides, moving the ball to the 1-yard line, Morton coach Bob Organ elected to go for two. 
“My mindset is I’ll take our offense four downs at the 10-yard line any time,” Organ said. “We found that out last week. When they jumped, I looked at Gipson in the huddle and said, ‘Go win the game.’” 
Gipson, a 6-2, 240-pound senior tight end/linebacker, was stuffed on a two-point conversion run at the end of the season-opening 19-18 loss to Riverside Brookfield, so he wasn’t surprised when his number was called instead of Hoard, who had rushed for 171 yards and two touchdowns on 34 carries. 
“No, when they jumped I knew coach was on the same page and I just wanted to win the game,” Gipson said. “The same thing happened against RB. I was not going to be denied this time.” 
The Mustangs faked a toss to Hoard and Gipson barreled up the middle. 
“I knew he was going to get it,” Organ said. “There was no doubt in my mind. 
“As soon as he came back to me I said, ‘no more RB.’ That’s off his mind now because he took [the RB loss] hard.” 
This had the makings of another hard-luck loss. The Mustangs had a punt blocked on their opening possession and Leyden’s Jalen Moore scored on an 11-yard run on the ensuing play. 
Morton lost a fumble on its second possession and a bad punt snap on the third series gave the Eagles the ball at the Mustangs 8-yard line. 
But junior corner back Santino Novakowski stopped Leyden quarterback Michael Wilms for a three-yard loss on fourth-and-goal from the 1-yard line. 
Novakowski later had a strip and his first career fumble recovery and a pair of pass deflections as the Morton defense allowed just 173 yards of total offense. 
“The whole week the coaches told us the plays that they were going to run, so we’ve been busting our butts,” Novakowski said. “The scout offense did good running their plays and the defense stepped up. That’s all that matters.” 
Morton tied the game on Hoard’s 18-yard run with eight seconds left in the first half, but Leyden’s Dominic Fredrickson returned an interception 36 yards for a touchdown to put the Eagles ahead 14-7 at the 8:08 mark of the fourth quarter. 
Yet the Mustangs prevailed. 
“Adversity is a big thing that comes our way so we learned how to tough it through,” Gipson said. “We said we’ve been through this before and we’re going to come out on top this time. That’s what we did.” 
– 
Who: Morton at Hinsdale South 
When: 7:30 p.m Oct. 23 
Where: 7401 Clarendon Hills Road 
Records: Morton 3-5 (3-2 WSG), Hinsdale South 5-3 (4-1) 
Outlook: The Mustangs are out of the playoff chase but they can still play the role of spoiler for Hinsdale South, which needs a win to secure a playoff spot. The Hornets are the highest-scoring offense in the West Suburban Gold, scoring nearly 35 points per game.
